thread.title: Off the tarmac and onto the water: Neil Marshall dominates jetsprints
thread.title_full: Off the tarmac and onto the water: Neil Marshall dominates jetsprints

author: Jeremy Wilkinson
title: Off the tarmac and onto the water: Neil Marshall dominates jetsprints
text:
* Taranaki's action-packed weekend greets crowds of thousands Ian Thornton 
Neil "Big Deal" Marshall is leading the pack heading into round three of the national jetsprint championships on Sunday. 
Marshall is currently leading the group A class for round three of the national championships, which Waitara's aquatrack has secured for the second time this series. 
Racing alongside his partner and navigator Michelle Reid the duo will be gunning to keep their top spot on the podium. 
"It's pretty competitive out there, it really comes down to who makes a mistake first," he said. Deane Riddick 
The new track layout at the Waitara jetsprint track. 
He's been plagued by breakdowns - like most jetsprint drivers - this year but is rearing to go come this weekend. Ad Feedback 
"This sport is extremely hard on engines because you've got your foot flat to the board most of the time," he said. 
"As opposed to rally where you're slowing down and speeding up, this is just full-throttle the whole time. ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
Waitara's jetsprint track in its first national championship showcase in 2015. 
"You need a bloody good engine to handle it." 
Despite racing on home-turf he hasn't had a chance to get in a practice at the Joll St track, so he'll be going in on-par with the other competitors. 
Track owner and driver Leighton Minnell won't be racing the iconic Taranaki Hardcore boat due to a breakdown, but he'll be there to cheer his wife Kellie on from the sidelines. 
"She's actually coming in fourth for the group B's at the moment, I think there were a few dropped-lips that the only all-girls team is putting the pressure on the men," he said. 
Round one of the championship was hosted at the track in December but after some issues getting consent for the track in Wairarapa, Taranaki was given two-rounds of the competition. 
Minnell said Marshall was known as Neil "Big Deal" in New Plymouth, and was happy to see such a large representation of Taranaki-based teams in the championship. 
"He's well-known from the Tarmac Rally and now he's carving up on the water," he said. 
Minnell is hopeful the weather will hold for the predicted sunny Sunday as last time round rain impacted the number crowd-members willing to sit in the rain. - Stuff
